Message.Title: High-risk Broadcom UPnP stack remote root vulnerability - may be the reason for today's sell-off?
Message.Msg: Recently, DefenseCode researchers have uncovered a remote root access vulnerability in the default installation of Linksys routers. Further research revealed that the vulnerability is even more dangerous, since the same vulnerable firmware component is also used by numerous other router manufacturers. The vulnerability is located within the wanipc and wanppp modules of the Broadcom UPnP stack, which is used by manufacturers that deliver routers based on the Broadcom chipset. A variety of routers have their UPnP interface available over the WAN interface, so the vulnerability can also be exploited over the Internet. It seems that, at the moment, the only popular UPnP implementation not hit by the remote preauth security vulnerability is MiniUPnP. The remote preauth format string vulnerability in the Broadcom UPnP stack can be exploited to write arbitrary values to an arbitrary memory address, and also to remotely read router memory. When exploited, it allows an unauthenticated attacker to execute arbitrary code under the root account. net-securityDOTorg/secworld.php?id=14335 BAD, BAD NEWS whosunw! Couldn't even wished anything worse than this on you!

Message.Title: Apple shrinks BRCM sales view, Samsung looms...
Message.Msg: Apple (AAPL)-related woes may be largely to blame for Broadcom's (BRCM) lower-than-expected Q1 revenue outlook, analysts say, but the chipmaker could see more upside from Apple's smartphone rival, Samsung. Shares in Broadcom were little changed in early trading Wednesday. The chipmaker's Q4 profit of 45 cents per share beat views. It announced a 10% hike in its annual dividend to 11 cents per share. Broadcom said it expects Q1 revenue of $1.9 billion, missing consensus estimates by 5%. Analysts said the guidance was tied to Apple as well as lower spending by phone companies on their networks. But Broadcom supplies wireless chips to Samsung as well as Apple and isn't as dependent on Apple's fortunes in the smartphone market as some other chipmakers, like Cirrus Logic (CRUS), analysts say. "With weakness at Apple now apparent and infrastructure weakness widespread, we suspect the shock value has been minimized," said Citigroup analyst Glen Yeung in a research note. "While the battle between Apple and Samsung will wage on, we continue to view (chip) suppliers as a good way to avoid choosing the winner. When considering Broadcom's opportunities in related technologies, we view BRCM as a good way to gain exposure to major communications trends." Jefferies analyst Mark Lipacis was upbeat in a report published Wednesday. "We think the company is conservative and believe its new 3G product cycle at Samsung and 5th-gen WiFi products for handsets and routers give it better visibility than most," wrote Lipacis. "We've also argued that positive investor sentiment will shift from Apple to Samsung due to its product cycle." Nomura analyst Romit Shah said: "We believe Broadcom is one of the few names in semis that is not pricing in a stronger economic recovery. The company has potentially set a low bar by refusing to call a bottom. "While we are aware of the weakness at Apple, we expected Samsung and (Wi-Fi) to provide a bigger offset this quarter," Shah added. SOURCE: Investor Business Daily ________ I was saying EXACTLY the same thing on the day BRCM reported its earnings and guidance, but was attacked by a hysterical poster on this board. I guess she needs to hear it from an 'authoritative" source - well, here it is.

Message.Title: Why Is Nvidia Obviously Pushing Tegra for Tablets over Phones
Message.Msg: Nvidia is pushing Tegra into tablets for 5 reasons: 1) Average Selling Price of Tegra is significantly higher in Tablets compared to phones. 2) Nvidia comes from a PC background. Easier to play in a playground your familiar with and well respected in. Yougher slog in phones. 3) 100's of potential Tablet vendor customers vs. 10's of phone vendor customers. No one customer can burn them like Samsung did in 2011. 4) PC Systems engineering knowledge is much more valuable when working with Tablets. 5) Gaming - Link to discrete Nvidia GPUs through Tegra 4 chip. Project shield is a demonstration of what is possible now and later with Nvidia Grid. Remember Nvidia's management is a bunch of middle aged gamers who know where their salaries come from.

A replay of the conference call will be available via telephone until we decide to take it down, and the webcast will be available for replay until our conference call to discuss our financial results for our fourth quarter of fiscal 2013. The content of today's conference call is NVIDIA's property and cannot be reproduced or transcribed without our prior written consent. During the course of this call, we may make forward-looking statements based on current expectations. These forward-looking statements are subject to a number of significant risks and uncertainties, and our actual results may differ materially. For a discussion of factors that could affect our future financial results and business, please refer to the disclosure in today's earnings release, our Form 10-Q for the fiscal quarter, and the reports we may file from time to time on Form 8-K filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission. Message.Title: Nvida to dominate mobile using same strategy as applied in GPU business model
Message.Msg: I'm very encouraged by the rumors that NVDA will be building reference smartphones and tablets. IMO, mobile is about to transiton from an era of brand differentiated devices (ala Apple) to a proliferation of private labeled devices that will disrupt the domination by Samsung, Apple A sure sign is the fall off of Apple brand enthusiasm over the past year. The Apple brand accounted a significant component of the percieved value by consumers. But this year Samsung has proven the Apple armor is not durable and Apple's brand was penetrated by feature superiority and increased functional value. Proving that consumers buying motivations can change very fast. Initially Nvidia has found itself in an less than optimal position by having to compete for SOC business with QCOM (and other chip companies) on the basis of a single chip as opposed to a system. The entry of the Shield device (and hopefully other mobile devices soon ) exposes a strategy designed to leverage their core competency which is to produce completely functional reference designs and use a bevy of manufacturers, just as they do now in the GPU space to penetrate markets on behlaf or Nvidia for example, there are dozens of companies across the globe that sell almost identical Nvdiia GPUs cards but with slight differences ( packaging, clock rates, cooling etc.) - but a 690 GTX is a 690 GTX no matter which company you buy it from . EVGA may have a better warranty, or is slighlty more overclocked, but beyond that, not much difference. Why not enable the same eco system in mobile devices? The seemingly endless growth of mobile is powered by both consumer adoption rates and a very fast (2 year replacement) ) device refresh cycle and in a market in which brand loyalty gives way to price , feature and function. Nvidia is well suited to exploit this market transition and to focus on China and India where price sensitity is greatet is brilliant Nvidia was never a graphics chip company - it was a graphics card company Reference designs of GPU Cards - not Graphic chips Reference designs mobile devices - not Mobile SOCs Let Samsung and Apple battle for Brand Nvidia will become the mobile device " arms dealer" to a bevy of regional manufacturers that will steal market share from - riding on Nvidia reference designs all the way to the bank gee, why not a Walmart phone?

Topic.Title: Toshiba first to adpot Nvidia's Tegra 4 platform, DigiTimes says

Message.Msg: Toshiba first to adopt Tegra 4, say Taiwan makers Monica Chen, Taipei; Joseph Tsai, DIGITIMES [Friday 1 February 2013] Toshiba, among tablet and smartphone vendors, is so far the Only one to adopt Nvidia's Tegra 4 platform for tablets to be launched in June 2013, implying that Tegra 4 is Struggling to compete with quad-core platforms developed by Qualcomm, MediaTek and China-based IC design houses, according to Taiwan-based supply chain makers. Asustek Computer and Acer, which have been aggressive about the tablet market, have not yet decided whether to place orders for Tegra 4 as their focuses have already turned from 10-inch and above tablets to the 7-inch entry-level segment. As for Asustek's smartphone product line, the company's close partnership with Qualcomm is likely to prompt the two firms to continue smartphone cooperation in the future, leaving Tegra 4 to become just a Backup solution, the sources noted. To regain its momentum, Nvidia is considering Reducing the Tegra 3's price to attract entry-level orders from brand vendors; however, the sources pointed out that even with a cut, Tegra 3's price is still not likely to become competitive against solutions from MediaTek and China-based IC design houses in terms of price." Tegra #4 : She's lookin' like a scratch, boys.

Topic.Title: Nvidia struggles to convince tablet vendors about Tegra 4

Message.Msg: "Toshiba, among tablet and smartphone vendors, is so far the only one to adopt Nvidia's Tegra 4 platform for tablets to be launched in June 2013, implying that Tegra 4 is struggling to compete with quad-core platforms developed by Qualcomm, MediaTek and China-based IC design houses, according to Taiwan-based supply chain makers. Asustek Computer and Acer, which have been aggressive about the tablet market, have not yet decided whether to place orders for Tegra 4 as their focuses have already turned from 10-inch and above tablets to the 7-inch entry-level segment. As for Asustek's smartphone product line, the company's close partnership with Qualcomm is likely to prompt the two firms to continue smartphone cooperation in the future, leaving Tegra 4 to become just a backup solution, the sources noted. To regain its momentum, Nvidia is considering reducing the Tegra 3's price to attract entry-level orders from brand vendors; however, the sources pointed out that even with a cut, Tegra 3's price is still not likely to become competitive against solutions from MediaTek and China-based IC design houses in terms of price." digitimesDOTcom/news/a20130201PD209.html

The Wall Street Journal reports, citing "sources", Sony will unveil the next-generation console and ship it by Christmas 2013. Sony is said to have scheduled the early event to beat Microsoft to its introduction of the Xbox 720. This tactic has been previously rumoured. In its event teaser, Sony was light on details as to what we might see at the event. Given the Wall Street Journal's reputation and other rumours, their report seems very likely. Message.Title: Nvidia struggles to convince vendors to adopt Tegra 4
Message.Msg: Consumers will not see a lot of Nvidia Tegra 4-based smartphones and tablets in the later part of 2013, according to reports out of Taiwan. The Tegra 4 features 72 custom Nvidia GeForce GPU cores, which is purported to boast six times more horsepower than its predecessor—the Tegra 3. It also includes ARM’s quad-core Cortex A15 architecture, and 4G LTE voice and data support with the optional Nvidia Icera i500 chipset. Despite the performance increase as well as added functionalities in the Tegra 4, it seems like Santa Clara-based chip maker is struggling to woo tablet and smartphone vendors to adopt its next-gen SoC. According to DigiTimes, Toshiba is the only vendor, thus far, to confirm the launch of Tegra 4-based tablets some time in mid-2013. Major OEMs like Asus and Acer are putting a lot of effort into developing ARM tablets, but they have not confirmed any orders of Tegra 4. Asus has close ties with Qualcomm in the smartphone department, so it’s likely that Asus will continue to use ARM chips from Qualcomm for future smartphones. Rather than forcing the issues with the Tegra 4, Nvidia will try to remain relevant by lowering the price of its Tegra 3 to attract vendors that are developing entry-level devices. However, even with a price cut on the Tegra 3, there are still cheaper solutions coming from MediaTek and other China-based chip makers.

Message.Title: NVDA notes may be effecting stock performance
Message.Msg: Barclays Sells First Uridashi Notes Tied to Nvidia #$%$&P Gains http://www.bloomberg.com/news/2013-02-01/barclays-sells-first-uridashi-notes-tied-to-nvidia-as-s-p-gains.html?cmpid=yhoo "Barclays’s five-month notes yield 9.02 percent monthly as long as Nvidia shares are at or above 90 percent of the stock’s Jan. 31 closing, while the coupon drops to 0.5 percent if the price falls by more than the 10 percent buffer, according to the prospectus for the product. If the shares gain more than 10 percent, the notes are redeemed at their full value. Should the stock close below 90 percent of its initial value on any day between Feb. 1 and 10 trading days before expiration on June 21, the notes convert into the Nvidia stock at maturity, according to the marketing materials. Nvidia shares closed at $12.26 on Jan. 31, after losing 34 percent of their value through last year since the end of 2009. In the latest earnings release in November, the company reported quarterly profit surpassing analysts’ estimates, helped by sales of chips used in tablet devices. Marina Totsuka, a Tokyo-based spokeswoman for Barclays, declined to comment on the reasons it picked the stock for the notes. "

Topic.Title: Digitimes article is wrong

Message.Msg: You need to understand the basic difference between telco and PC//tablet before making an intelligent comment. Number one: the telco industry has an extremely high entry barrier, meaning that you can't just make a few phones here and there to try things out - you need CARRIERS, CARRIERS and CARRIERS who command huge volumes. That is why in the consumer business division of NVIDIA, there seems to be more senior management members than in a traditional tech/semi/PC company. They need the top guys to pitch their products (either handsets of components of handsets) to the senior execs of a carrier (usually VP) who are the decision makers. The component suppliers for a handset CAN"T just send a middle level manager to negotiate large contract - their counterpart simply won't talk to them. That is the reason for being seeming "top heavy" as phrased by some clueless posters. On the other hand, in the pharmaceutical industry, most of the sales are done by reps/details who call on physicians, thus the ratio of reps vs top echelon is entirely different. You can't just compare apples with oranges, or extrapolate a limited experience in one industry to another. Sick and tired of clueless comments.

Topic.Title: Digitimes article is wrong

Message.Msg: Ibexx, The Consumer Products Division is top heavy with senior management because that's where most of employees went from the former Chipset division. Remember it was approaching $1B in annual sales so it was pretty large. All good people for sure, and that's why they could whip up the Project Shield console on a moments notice, but none of them had any experience working with phones or telcos coming from a PC background. Since Nvidia is a NO LAYOFF company and all of the Chipset senior management had been with Nvidia almost from inception...they all got to keep their titles which really don't mean anything anymore in the Semiconductor industry. I do believe this cadre of people from the old chipset division is behind Nvidia's more recent PC centric push into Tablets and Gaming with Phones taking the back burner. Not a bad thing, but those people who may be in Nvidia for the phone business might want to re think their position or at least wait another 12 months or so for any meaningful phone growth. GPUs, High performance Computing, and Tablets are this year's growth drivers. JMHO

Topic.Title: Nvidia struggles to convince vendors to adopt Tegra 4

Message.Msg: The undertone of the articles are that Tegra 4 is late to a crowded 28nm and already entrenched generation. What Tegra 4 has is that it packs a lot for its size... very small 80 sq mm die... margins will be very good, along with Tegra 4 being cheap... And NVidia drivers...

Topic.Title: NVDA notes may be effecting stock performance

Message.Msg: Great another reason for somone to want the price to drop.

Topic.Title: Nvidia struggles to convince vendors to adopt Tegra 4

Message.Msg: Tegra 4's competitor is Snapdragon 800, which is due out the second half of 2013 and NOT integrated with a LTE radio at first glance. Tegra 4 has a number of second tier products already announced (ViZIO tablet, XOLO phone of India) and some leaked ones (Nexus 5, Nexus 7.7, HTC xxx flagship smartphone, Xiaomi M3 phone of China, Toshiba tablet etc), but nothing has been mentioned for Snapdragon 800 yet, not even rumors. Products based on both SoCs (Tegra 4 and Snapdragon 800) are intended for the middle of the year, and Tegra 4 gadgets likely will arrive a couple of months earlier than the Q 800 devices. Jen Hsun already said at the CES that individual vendors will announce their own product launches, and some will probably do so at the Barcelona meeting 3 weeks from now. So...any one wishes to comment on the design wins of Tegra 4 should put it into the context including Snapdragon 800. PS: The Digitimes article is obviously a hack job (some one already said this), and I suspect that (!) there is price negotiation currently going on between NV and some vendors; (2) some vendors in Taiwan may be pi$$ed off by NV's decision to manufacture and market its own hardware. If NIVIDIA could keep Shield a highly guarded secret, they can, also, do this with product information. The vendors want their own spotlight.

Topic.Title: Nvidia struggles to convince vendors to adopt Tegra 4

It is expected to showcase Android 4.2 Jelly Bean as well. A gadget’s specifications of this sort from a less-known player like Xiaomi might leave your jaws dropped in awe. SOURCE: 0gadgetsDOTco/2013/01/15/xiaomi-m3-quad-core-tegra-4-powered-phone-quick-look/#.UQxQ4hwjHNo PS: Xiaomi is an extremely popular and well-known Chinese handset maker. It's previous products M1, M2 had been sell-off after market releases. M3 is rumored to be powered by Tegra 4 and will be launched in Q2.

The 2013 Microsoft Surface thrust will be completed by the 11.6-inch Surface Pro, which according to MS_Nerd will be powered by AMD's Temash APU." Message.Title: "Vizio's first Windows 8 tablet: hands-on with the AMD-powered, 1080p slate"
Message.Msg: "Vizio's first Windows 8 tablet: hands-on with the AMD-powered, 1080p slate" "it's a really good screen, but it creates some consequences. Intel's processors simply couldn't power such a dense, high-res screen, Vizio CTO Matt McRae told us, so the company used AMD chips instead. The Tablet is powered by a dual-core, 1GHz Z-60 processor, which based on our time with the device does a pretty good job powering Windows 8." Intel couldn't cut it and Tegra 4 can't run the full Windows 8 now, can it? Limping RT for Tegra 4 in some no name white box or the highway. Windows 8 require real x86 horsepower. imho

Message.Title: Why Nvidia is Pushing Tablets over Phones....
Message.Msg: Average Selling Price has to be higher. Compare Q3 CPD revenue and operating income to Q2 sales and operating income and you will see why. Up until late Q2 2012 phones and Tablet processor sales were equal but in Q3 Tablet Sales exploded. Q2 Revenue $180M Oper. Loss -$90M Q3 Revenue $244M Oper. Loss -$42M In other words a revenue increase of $64M generated $48M to the bottom line. That is a gross margin of 75% for Tegra sold in tablets. It's obvious why they are pushing tablets over phones. Sure if someone wants to pay full price in phones they will take it. After all the phone mfg. have to keep QCOM honest on the price, so a nibble here are there will happen. Those expecting big phone announcements will be dissappointed I'am afraid. But we did get a design win on a KungFu phone in China this week. By the Way the Russian OEM that was mentioned in that piece on Nvidia reference designs...Wexler holds 35% of the Russian/East European tablet market with their current bestseller a Tegra 3 tablet. Now this Project Shield thing is intriguing. If everyone is sold at profit, what is the worry? Mucho MCP guys around with the skills and experience to design hardware. Back in the day when Nvidia built chipsets, Intel would withhold tech info and samples until they had their chipsets ready for production and these same guys had a better Nvidia chipset ready when Intel launched the new processor. I bet they were clamoring to be on on the team. Besides THE BUZZ from the announcement is PRICELESS! Sometimes holding on to redundancies is worth it. JMHO

Message.Title: Hope this is true - Tegra 4 in HTC flagship phone M7
Message.Msg: Nvidia Tegra 4 chipset powers the HTC M7 January 28, 2013 ""Getting back to our today’s news HTC’s 2013 flagship smartphone — HTC M7 that we’ve seen captured in a couple of photos, according to one of our trusted sources will feature Nvidia’s most recent Tegra 4 chipset that features 72 custom NVIDIA GeForce GPU cores which if someone wonders has six times the GPU horsepower of Tegra 3, that’s how powerful these chips are, and to top that this is the first quad-core CPU in it’s portfolio to sport LTE technology, so no one will have to worry about 4G connectivity on the next flagship HTC M7. Another requirement criteria was that HTC needed a chipset powerful enough to highlight their Full HD Super LCD screen an easy task for Tegra 4 chips considering that it also has 4K ultra-high-definition video support embedded."" pocketdroidDOTnet/nvidia-tegra-4-chipset-powers-htc-m7/
